pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 185, 905, 243]]<|/det|>
0625/21 May/June 2017 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 247, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 311, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 371, 892, 400]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 458, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 548, 358, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 798, 89]]<|/det|>
What is the most accurate and precise method to measure the thickness of a coin?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 415, 117]]<|/det|>
Use a micrometer screw gauge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 556, 144]]<|/det|>
Use a ruler and look at the scale perpendicularly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 346, 170]]<|/det|>
Use a top pan balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 690, 196]]<|/det|>
Use the displacement method with water in a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 222, 96, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 574, 241]]<|/det|>
On Earth, a ball is dropped and falls \(2.0 \text{m}\) in a vacuum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 507, 271]]<|/det|>
The acceleration of the ball at \(1.0 \text{m}\) is \(10 \text{m/s}^2\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 278, 620, 481]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 495, 485, 514]]<|/det|>
What is the acceleration of the ball at \(0.5 \text{m}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 523, 133, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 523, 228, 542]]<|/det|>
5.0 m/s²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 523, 300, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 523, 390, 542]]<|/det|>
10 m/s²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 523, 468, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 523, 556, 542]]<|/det|>
15 m/s²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 523, 636, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 523, 725, 542]]<|/det|>
20 m/s²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 567, 96, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 670, 586]]<|/det|>
A skydiver reaches terminal velocity. Then he opens his parachute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 598, 574, 616]]<|/det|>
What happens to the skydiver as the parachute opens?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 626, 133, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 626, 403, 644]]<|/det|>
There is a decrease in weight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 133, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 653, 403, 670]]<|/det|>
There is acceleration upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 680, 133, 697]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 680, 403, 697]]<|/det|>
There is an increase in speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 706, 133, 724]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 706, 393, 724]]<|/det|>
There is movement upwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A piece of steel is taken from the Earth to the Moon for an experiment. The gravitational field strength on the Moon is smaller than on the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 544, 134]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the piece of steel is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 133, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 144, 549, 163]]<|/det|>
It has less mass on the Moon than on the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 133, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 170, 559, 188]]<|/det|>
It has more mass on the Moon than on the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 131, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 198, 527, 215]]<|/det|>
It weighs less on the Moon than on the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 223, 133, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 223, 537, 240]]<|/det|>
It weighs more on the Moon than on the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 96, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 922, 301]]<|/det|>
A measuring cylinder containing only water is placed on an electronic balance. A small, irregularly shaped stone is now completely immersed in the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 730, 331]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show the equipment before and after the stone is immersed.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 339, 819, 687]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 700, 512, 718]]<|/det|>
What is the density of the material of the stone?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 728, 133, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 728, 238, 746]]<|/det|>
1.7 g/ cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 728, 303, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 728, 403, 746]]<|/det|>
3.3 g/ cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 728, 470, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 728, 571, 746]]<|/det|>
4.5 g/ cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 728, 636, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 728, 737, 746]]<|/det|>
8.7 g/ cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 794, 91]]<|/det|>
A boat is travelling at a steady speed in a straight line across the surface of a lake.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 472, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the boat is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 131, 133, 148]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 638, 148]]<|/det|>
The resultant force on the boat is in the direction of motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 158, 131, 176]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 737, 175]]<|/det|>
The resultant force on the boat is in the opposite direction to its motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 606, 201]]<|/det|>
The resultant force on the boat is vertically downwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 210, 133, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 472, 227]]<|/det|>
The resultant force on the boat is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 97, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 253, 631, 272]]<|/det|>
A ball of weight 1.2 N drops through the air at terminal velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 284, 771, 301]]<|/det|>
A sudden gust of wind exerts a horizontal force of \(0.5 \text{N}\) on the ball from the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 314, 764, 331]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the resultant force on the ball while the wind is blowing?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 341, 769, 504]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 545, 324, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 570, 438, 789]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[633, 545, 653, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[532, 574, 791, 714]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 710, 91]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a uniform bridge, \(4.0 \text{m}\) long and weighing \(10 000 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
The bridge is pivoted at one end. A force at the other end gradually increases until the bridge begins to lift.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 144, 725, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 260, 628, 280]]<|/det|>
What is the lifting force as the bridge starts to move upwards?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 289, 134, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 289, 212, 307]]<|/det|>
2500 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 289, 300, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 289, 384, 307]]<|/det|>
5000 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 289, 468, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 289, 512, 307]]<|/det|>
10000 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 289, 636, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 289, 728, 307]]<|/det|>
20000 N

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 335, 92, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 335, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
A bullet of mass \(0.10 \text{kg}\) travels horizontally at a speed of \(600 \text{m / s}\). It strikes a stationary wooden block of mass \(1.90 \text{kg}\) resting on a frictionless, horizontal surface.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 353, 398]]<|/det|>
The bullet stays in the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 410, 732, 428]]<|/det|>
What is the speed of the bullet and the block immediately after the impact?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 438, 134, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 438, 165, 456]]<|/det|>
30 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 438, 298, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 438, 384, 456]]<|/det|>
32 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 438, 467, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 438, 500, 456]]<|/det|>
60 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 438, 635, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 438, 675, 456]]<|/det|>
134 m/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 905, 89]]<|/det|> A box of mass \(m\) slides down a slope of length \(l\) and vertical height \(d\) against a frictional force \(F\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 100, 732, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 274, 922, 308]]<|/det|> As the box slides down the slope, it loses gravitational potential energy and it does work against the friction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 319, 880, 338]]<|/det|> Which row gives the loss in gravitational potential energy and the work done against friction? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 348, 598, 497]]<|/det|>
loss in gravitational potential energywork done against friction
Amgd\(Fl\)
Bmgd\(Fd\)
C\(mgl\)\(Fl\)
D\(mgl\)\(Fd\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 521, 106, 540]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 593, 540]]<|/det|> The diagram represents the energy transfers for a device. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 549, 734, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 732, 344, 749]]<|/det|> The device is \(50\%\) efficient. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 762, 339, 780]]<|/det|> Which equation is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 791, 134, 809]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 791, 479, 809]]<|/det|> input energy = useful output energy \(\div\) 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 819, 131, 836]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 819, 554, 836]]<|/det|> useful output energy = wasted output energy \(\div\) 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 845, 131, 863]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 845, 522, 863]]<|/det|> wasted output energy = useful output energy <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 872, 133, 890]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 872, 554, 890]]<|/det|> wasted output energy = useful output energy \(\div\) 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 487, 91]]<|/det|>
A student carries out some simple exercises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 457, 120]]<|/det|>
In which exercise is the most work done?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 128, 887, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 444, 106, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 551, 462]]<|/det|>
Four different liquids are poured into four containers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 715, 492]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show the depth and the density of liquid in each container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 604, 523]]<|/det|>
In which container is the pressure on its base the greatest?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[139, 530, 858, 734]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 836, 89]]<|/det|>
Brownian motion is observed when using a microscope to look at smoke particles in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 561, 120]]<|/det|>
What causes the smoke particles to move at random?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 490, 147]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 650, 175]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles are moved by convection currents in the air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 700, 200]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles have different weights and fall at different speeds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 527, 227]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles hit the walls of the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 799, 272]]<|/det|>
Gas molecules striking a container wall cause a pressure to be exerted on the wall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 376, 301]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 134, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 312, 690, 330]]<|/det|>
When a molecule rebounds there must be a change in its energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 339, 134, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 725, 356]]<|/det|>
When a molecule rebounds there must be a change in its momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 134, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 685, 382]]<|/det|>
When a molecule rebounds there must be a change in its speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 134, 410]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 392, 735, 408]]<|/det|>
When a molecule rebounds there must be a change in its temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 668, 89]]<|/det|>
Equal masses of two different liquids are put into identical beakers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 856, 119]]<|/det|>
Liquid 1 is heated for 100 s and liquid 2 is heated for 200 s by heaters of the same power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 492, 149]]<|/det|>
Each liquid has the same rise in temperature.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 157, 833, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 348, 456]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 134, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 466, 589, 485]]<|/det|>
Each beaker of liquid has the same thermal capacity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 492, 131, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 492, 551, 510]]<|/det|>
Each beaker of liquid receives the same energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 518, 131, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 518, 515, 537]]<|/det|>
Liquid 1 receives more energy than liquid 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 545, 133, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 545, 769, 562]]<|/det|>
The thermal capacity of liquid 1 is less than the thermal capacity of liquid 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 590, 106, 607]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 922, 623]]<|/det|>
Water of mass \(100 \text{g}\) at a temperature of \(100^{\circ} \text{C}\) is converted into steam at \(100^{\circ} \text{C}\). The specific latent heat of vaporisation of water is \(2300 \text{J/g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 635, 554, 653]]<|/det|>
How much thermal energy is absorbed by the water?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 134, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 662, 176, 680]]<|/det|>
23J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 662, 306, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 662, 368, 680]]<|/det|>
230J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 662, 475, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 662, 567, 680]]<|/det|>
230000J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 662, 641, 680]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 662, 758, 680]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 834, 90]]<|/det|> Which diagram shows what happens when a ray of white light passes through a prism? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 100, 900, 452]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 473, 106, 492]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 473, 920, 508]]<|/det|> Light travels in a vacuum and then enters a glass block. The speed of the light in the glass block is \(2.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 546, 539]]<|/det|> Which statement about the speed of light is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 134, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 638, 567]]<|/det|> The speed in a vacuum is 1.5 times the speed in the glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 133, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 574, 663, 593]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is the same as the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 600, 133, 618]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 600, 638, 618]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is 1.5 times the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 133, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 628, 685, 645]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is \(1.0 \times 10^{8}\) times the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 670, 106, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 670, 922, 704]]<|/det|> A fire alarm is not loud enough and the pitch is too low. An engineer adjusts the alarm so that it produces a louder note of a higher pitch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 714, 777, 732]]<|/det|> What effect does this have on the amplitude and on the frequency of the sound? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 742, 430, 873]]<|/det|>

The fish are magnetically attracted to the end of the rod. There is no magnetic force between the fish themselves. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[268, 114, 727, 305]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 319, 702, 338]]<|/det|> What are possible materials from which the fish and the rod are made? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 349, 432, 477]]<|/det|>
fishrod

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 505, 107, 523]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 670, 523]]<|/det|> What is the most effective method of demagnetising a bar magnet? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 134, 552]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 534, 920, 567]]<|/det|> placing the magnet in a solenoid carrying a large alternating current and gradually decreasing the current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 134, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 575, 920, 609]]<|/det|> placing the magnet in a solenoid carrying a large direct current and gradually decreasing the current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 616, 134, 634]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 616, 920, 650]]<|/det|> placing the magnet in a solenoid that produces a magnetic field in the opposite direction to the magnet <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 657, 134, 675]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 657, 885, 675]]<|/det|> placing the magnet next to an identical bar magnet with its poles in the opposite direction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 701, 104, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 851, 720]]<|/det|> A magnet near a coil of wire is attracted to the coil only when there is a current in the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 732, 524, 749]]<|/det|> Which statement explains this force of attraction? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 759, 134, 778]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 759, 527, 778]]<|/det|> The coil of wire has its own gravitational field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 134, 804]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 787, 468, 804]]<|/det|> The coil of wire is made from soft iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 813, 134, 831]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 813, 599, 831]]<|/det|> The current in the coil of wire creates a magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 839, 134, 857]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 839, 667, 857]]<|/det|> The current in the coil of wire induces a charge on the magnet.

Light falls on the LDR. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 114, 616, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 255, 581, 273]]<|/det|> The brightness of the light falling on the LDR decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 285, 895, 303]]<|/det|> What happens to the resistance of the LDR and what happens to the reading on the ammeter? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 313, 480, 459]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> A simple d.c. electric motor is fitted with a coil that rotates in a magnetic field. A commutator connects the power supply to the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 450, 135]]<|/det|> What is the purpose of the commutator? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 144, 134, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 432, 163]]<|/det|> It converts a.c. into d.c. in the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 133, 190]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 170, 865, 188]]<|/det|> It prevents the current from becoming too great, because the coil has a low resistance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 133, 216]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 197, 839, 215]]<|/det|> It reverses the direction of the current in the coil after every \(180^{\circ}\) rotation of the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 225, 133, 243]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 224, 750, 242]]<|/det|> It switches the current off momentarily after every \(90^{\circ}\) rotation of the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 270, 106, 288]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 270, 376, 288]]<|/det|> What is the purpose of a relay? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 134, 316]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 298, 529, 316]]<|/det|> to change a large voltage into a small voltage <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 325, 134, 344]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 325, 529, 344]]<|/det|> to change a small voltage into a large voltage <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 131, 370]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 351, 561, 369]]<|/det|> to use a large current to switch on a small current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 377, 133, 396]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 377, 561, 395]]<|/det|> to use a small current to switch on a large current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 421, 106, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 737, 439]]<|/det|> Which row gives the relative charge of an electron, a neutron and a proton? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 468, 580]]<|/det|>
electronneutronproton
A-10-1
B-10+1
C+1-10
D+10+1
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 606, 106, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 606, 473, 625]]<|/det|> A nuclide of element X undergoes \(\beta\)-decay. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 637, 348, 655]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 664, 133, 682]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 664, 455, 682]]<|/det|> The nucleon number increases by 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 691, 133, 708]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 691, 460, 708]]<|/det|> The nucleon number stays the same. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 718, 133, 736]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 718, 559, 736]]<|/det|> The product is another nuclide of an isotope of X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 133, 762]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 744, 450, 762]]<|/det|> The proton number decreases by 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 480, 89]]<|/det|>
A sample of radioactive isotope is decaying.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 465, 120]]<|/det|>
The nuclei of which atoms will decay first?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 662, 147]]<|/det|>
It is impossible to know because radioactive decay is random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 131, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 675, 175]]<|/det|>
It is impossible to know unless the age of the material is known.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 873, 200]]<|/det|>
The atoms near the centre will decay first because they are surrounded by more atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 208, 890, 225]]<|/det|>
The atoms near the surface will decay first because the radiation can escape more easily.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 253, 106, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 777, 272]]<|/det|>
A detector of ionising radiation gives a background reading of 20 counts/minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
A radioactive isotope with a half-life of 2.0 days is brought near to the detector. The reading on the detector increases to 100 counts/minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 834, 348]]<|/det|>
How long does it take for the reading on the detector to decrease to 40 counts/minute?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 358, 133, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 358, 228, 376]]<|/det|>
2.0 days

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 358, 300, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 358, 393, 376]]<|/det|>
4.0 days

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 358, 468, 376]]<|/det|>
